.

But

There

Sylvia
Plath
:
A
Biographical
Note
by
Lois
Ames
With
eight
previously
unpublished
drawings
by
Sylvia
Plath
THE
Bell
JAR
was
first
published
in
London
in
January
1963
by
William
Heinemann
Limited
,
under
the
pseudonym
Victoria
Lucas
.
Sylvia
Plath
had
adopted
the
pen
name
for
publication
of
her
first
novel
because
she
questioned
its
literary
value
and
did
not
believe
it
was
a
``
serious
work
''
;
she
was
also
worried
about
the
pain
publication
might
cause
to
the
many
people
close
to
her
whose
personalities
she
had
distorted
and
lightly
disguised
in
the
book
.
The
central
themes
of
Sylvia
Plath
's
early
life
are
the
basis
for
The
Bell
Jar
.
She
was
born
in
1932
in
Massachusetts
and
spent
her
early
childhood
years
in
Winthrop
,
a
seaside
town
close
to
Boston
.
Her
mother
's
parents
were
Austrian
;
her
father
,
a
distinguished
professor
of
biology
at
Boston
University
(
and
an
internationally
known
authority
on
bees
)
,
had
emigrated
to
the
States
from
Poland
as
an
adolescent
;
she
had
one
brother
,
two
and
a
half
years
younger
.
A
radical
change
occurred
in
Sylvia
's
life
when
she
was
eight
:
in
November
1940
,
her
father
died
after
a
long
,
difficult
illness
,
and
the
mother
and
grandparents
moved
the
family
inland
to
the
town
of
Wellesley
,
a
conservative
upper-middle-class
suburb
of
Boston
.
While
the
grandmother
assumed
the
care
of
the
household
,
Mrs.
Plath
taught
students
in
the
medical-secretarial
training
program
at
Boston
University
,
commuting
each
day
,
and
the
grandfather
worked
as
matre
d'htel
at
the
Brookline
Country
Club
,
where
he
lived
during
the
week
.
Sylvia
and
her
brother
attended
the
local
public
schools
.
``
I
went
to
public
schools
,
''
she
wrote
later
,
``
genuinely
public
.
Everyone
went
.
''
At
an
early
age
she
began
to
write
poems
and
to
draw
in
pen
and
ink
--
and
to
collect
prizes
with
her
first
publication
of
each
.
By
the
time
she
was
seventeen
,
her
interest
in
writing
had
become
disciplined
and
controlled
.
Publication
,
however
,
did
not
come
easily
;
she
had
submitted
forty-five
pieces
to
the
magazine
Seventeen
before
her
first
short
story
,
``
And
Summer
Will
Not
Come
Again
,
''
was
published
in
the
August
1950
issue
.
A
poem
,
``
Bitter
Strawberries
,
''
a
sardonic
comment
on
war
,
was
accepted
and
published
in
the
same
month
by
the
Christian
Science
Monitor
.
In
her
high
school
year
book
,
The
Wellesleyan
,
the
girl
who
later
described
herself
as
a
``
rabid
teenage
pragmatist
''
was
pictured
:
Warm
smile
.
.
.
energetic
worker
.
.
.
Bumble
Boogie
piano
special
.
.
.
Clever
with
chalk
and
paints
.
.
.
Weekends
at
Williams
.
.
.
Those
fully
packed
sandwiches
.
.
.
Future
writer
.
.
.
Those
rejection
slips
from
Seventeen
.
.
.
Oh
,
for
a
license
.
In

She

These

wrote
poetry
on
a

,
circled

red-leather

to

maintained

,

.
Highly

she
was

elected

the

,
went

men

.
But

wrote

``
for

I
may

,

.
''
Of

a
friend
later

:
``
It

Sylvia
could

wait
for
life

to
her
.
.
.
She
rushed
out
to
greet

,
to
make

.
''
As

became
increasingly
conscious
of
herself
as

woman

the
conflict

the

of
a

and

:
``
.
.
.it
's

amazing
how
I
've
gone
around
for

under

.
''
In

Then

``
We
thought
maybe
you
were
in
the
plot
,
''
said
Mrs.
McKisco
.
She
was
a
shabby-eyed
,
pretty
young
woman
with
a
disheartening
intensity
.
``
We
do
n't
know
who
's
in
the
plot
and
who
is
n't
.
One
man
my
husband
had
been
particularly
nice

turned

be
a
chief

--
practically

assistant

.
''
``
The
plot
?
''
inquired

,
half
understanding
.
``
Is
there
a
plot
?
''
``
My

,
we
do
n't
know
,
''
said
Mrs.
Abrams
,
with

's

``
We
're

.
We

gallery
.
''
Mr.
Dumphry
,
a

remarked

``
Mama
Abrams
is
a
plot

,
''

``
Now

Royal
,

''
Rosemary

She

Her

.
But
Rosemary

and
sometimes
the
French
manners
of
her
early

America

these

Mr.
McKisco
,
a

did
not

``
plot
''

He

sea

wife

turned
to
Rosemary
and

``
Been
here
long
?
''
``
Only

day
.
''
``
Oh
.
''
Evidently

in

.
``
Going

?
''

McKisco
,

.
``
If

.
''
``
For

,
Violet

drop

''

.
``
Get

,

''
Mrs.
McKisco
swayed

Abrams
and
breathed

:
``
He
's
nervous
.
''
``
I
'm
not
nervous
,
''
disagreed

.
``
It
just
happens
I
'm
not
nervous

.
''
He
was

--
a

Suddenly

and

Rosemary

.
Mr.
McKisco
drew

a

obviously

his

he

.
``
I
have

.
I
never

.
''
He

``
I

''

``
And

''
``
The
breathing
's

.
Shall

?
''
The
man
with

,

As

a

.
``
I

.
''
His

he

Rosemary

the

He

McKisco

Rosemary

McKisco

.
When

,

.
``
He
's
a
good
swimmer
,
''
Rosemary

.
Mrs.
McKisco
's

with

.
``
Well
,
he
's
a
rotten

.
''
She
turned
to
her
husband
,
who
after
two
unsuccessful

had
managed

climb
on

raft
,
and
having

,
achieving
only

extra

.
``
I
was
just

that
Abe
North
may
be
a
good
swimmer
but
he
's
a
rotten

.
''
``
Yes
,
''
agreed
McKisco
,

.
Obviously

created

wife
's

,
and

.
``
Antheil
's

.
''
Mrs.
McKisco

,
``
Anthiel

Joyce
.
I

.
''
``

``

''
``
He

Her

The

The

``
Is

?
''

``
No

Mrs.
Diver
.
They

.
''
Her

woman
's

After

``
Have

?
''
``
Yes

.
''
``

.

.

''

``
Oh

?
''
She

``

''
Rosemary

The

Noon

It

Campion

.
The

Rosemary

She

As

``
I

.
It

''
``
Thank

.
''
Rosemary

``
Heavens
!
''
She

He

He

.
``
Do

?
''

``
It

.
''
They

``
It

''

.
``

''
He

Then

.
III
It
was
almost
two
when
they
went
into
the
dining-room
.
Back
and
forth

deserted
tables
a
heavy

of
beams
and
shadows
swayed
with
the
motion
of
the
pines
outside
.
Two
waiters
,
piling

and
talking

Italian
,
fell
silent
when
they
came
in
and
brought
them
a
tired
version
of
the
table
d'hte
luncheon
.
``
I
fell
in
love

the
beach
,
''
said
Rosemary
.
``
Who
with
?
''
``
First

a
whole
lot

people
who
looked
nice
.
Then

one
man
.
''
``
Did
you
talk

him
?
''
``
Just
a
little
.
Very
handsome
.
With
reddish
hair
.
''
She

.
``
He

married

--

's

.
''
Her

had
put
every

the
guiding
of
her
,
not
so
rare
a
thing
in
the
theatrical

,
but
rather

that

Elsie

She

no

--
twice

.
One

had
been

and

and

something

present

Rosemary
.
By

she

her

--
by
not

she
had

in
Rosemary
,
which
at
present
was

saw

.
So
that

a
``
simple
''

by

of
her
mother

--
she

,
the

and

.
However

Rosemary
's
sudden
success
in
pictures
Mrs.
Speers
felt
that
it
was
time
she
were
spiritually

it

than

if
this
somewhat

,
breathless

exigent

would
focus

something

.
``
Then
you
like
it
here
?
''
she
asked
.
``
It
might
be
fun
if
we
knew
those
people
.
There
were
some
other
people
,
but
they
were
n't
nice
.
They
recognized
me
--
no
matter
where
we
go
everybody
's
seen
'Daddy
's
Girl
.
'
''
Mrs.
Speers
waited

glow

subside

then

``
That

?
''
``
I

.
''
``
You

--
I
'm

.
''
``
We

.
''
``
I

.
It

--

n't

n't

.
''
``
Mother

''
``
Oh

.
''
``
All

Mother
.
''
After

they
were

by
the
sudden

that
comes

.
No

,
no

and

of

they
felt
that

was
not
continuing

.

Dick

XIX
Abe

XXIV
With

During

XIV
Dick
awoke
at
five
after
a
long
dream
of
war
,
walked
to
the
window
and
stared
out
it
at
the
Zugersee
.
His
dream
had
begun
in
sombre

;
navy
blue
uniforms
crossed
a
dark
plaza
behind
bands
playing
the
second

Prokofieff
's
``
Love
of
Three
Oranges
.
''
Presently

,

disaster
,

a

in

.
He

``
Non-combatant
's

.
''
As

.
In

Nicole
muttered

desolate
and
he
felt
sorry

whatever

For

.
Even

,

She

The

They

the
other

.
She
led

owning
Dick
who

Many

They

Nothing

He

Later

Lanier

''
Half

Like

The

Himself

The

IV
The
Divers
would

the
Riviera
,
which
was
home
.
The

again

so

between

Dick

no

;
it

one

those

that
is
an

not

's

which

nor

but
simply

.
The

that

the

Dick
's

increased

,
now

He
managed

reach

over

He

They

content

simple

They
lived

found

in

of

Dick

,

Lanier

Dick

XII
The

Diver

He

The
